issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.
status.name: Open

fields.description:
Lots of good feedback from Lincoln. Can split off into separate tickets if needed (remove and move if you do that).

Here’s a set of things I’ve noticed in my use of the docs so far…
Feel free to ask others if unsure, I may have things wrong here and not even know it!

1. http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/master/#user-guide/login_instance.html 
At the Log On to Windows prompt, prepend the user name Administrator to the public IP address of the instance, and enter the password that you retrieved with euca-get-password, as shown:

In the screen shot, it’s “User name: 192.168.7.225\Administrator”, so shouldn’t it be append?

2. http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/master/#shared/create_ebs_volume.html
Create a new EBS volume in the same availability zone as the running instance. 
euca-create-volume --zone zone1 --size 10

--zone doesn’t work, has to be either -z (one hyphen) or --availability-zone (two hyphens) :

[root@g-15-06 lincoln]# euca-create-volume --zone two --size 1
usage: euca-create-volume -z ZONE [-s GiB] [--snapshot SNAPSHOT] [-t VOLTYPE]
                          [-i IOPS] [--show-empty-fields] [-U URL]
                          [--region USER@REGION] [-I KEY_ID] [-S KEY]
                          [--security-token TOKEN] [--debug] [--debugger]
                          [--version] [-h]
euca-create-volume: error: argument -z/--availability-zone is required
[root@g-15-06 lincoln]# euca-create-volume --availability-zone two --size 1
VOLUME  vol-28b734c4    1               two     creating        2015-10-22T14:15:48.285Z

3. http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/master/#user-guide/monitoring_disabling.html
Look for the word “enable”. Should some/all of those be “disable”? Cut & paste error?

4. http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/master/#install-guide/planning_edge.html
Global network updates (such as security group rule updates, security group VM membership updates, and elastic IP updates) are be applied through an "eventually consistent" mechanism, as opposed to an "atomic" mechanism.
Wording?

5. *Update: Ignore this, not an issue.*
http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.0/#euca2ools-guide/euca-reboot-instances.html
euca-reboot-instances instance_id [instance_id ...]
…but:
http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.0/#release-notes/3.2.0/3.2.0_rn_issues.html
euca-reboot-instances only reboots one instance, even if multiple instances are specified (EUCA-4268)
euca-reboot-instances reboots the first instance specified. To reboot multiple instances, run euca-reboot-instances once per instance.
Should the CLI doc be changed to show only one instance_id param until it’s fixed? (Might be a while)
*[Lincoln] Update: This was a Known Issue in 3.2.0, but then fixed in 3.2.1 which I hadn't seen. So, the docs are correct. Nothing to see here, move along, move along...*

6. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.0/#user-guide/run_instance.html
euca-run-instances emi-EC1410C1 

This will indeed work, but you won’t be able to log in, unless you provide a keypair as well, e.g.:

euca-run-instances emi-EC1410C1 -k <keypair_name>

I discovered this when I went on to the next step http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.0/#user-guide/login_instance.html and couldn’t ssh to the instance, even after authorizing the default security group for ssh as described in http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.0/#user-guide/authorize_sg.html.

The mgmt. console analogous section http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.0/#user-guide/run_instance_console.html is correct because it requires you to create and refer to a keypair when launching an instance. 

7. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.0/#install-guide/installing_euca_nightlies.html
I believe the nightly version should be:
yum install http://downloads.eucalyptus.com/software/euca2ools/nightly/3.3/centos/6/x86_64/euca2ools-release-nightly-3.3-1.el6.noarch.rpm - THIS IS FIXED via DOC-1700

8. euca- vs euserv- CLI commands (general) - Is there a to-do to change all the deprecated euca- commands to their euserv- replacements? E.g. I see both euca-describe-services and euserv-describe-services in the docs in different places. 

The CLI reference is probably the most important place. E.g. I see euca-describe-services in the http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.0/#euca2ools-guide/admin_commands.html but not euserv-describe-services. Maybe they should both be on that CLI reference page (so people can find it either way) and say that the euca- is deprecated?
THIS IS DOC-1717

9. Tomography
http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.0/#install-guide/preparing_connectivity.html 

This is the network-tomography tool we emailed about (24-Nov).  You can use output text from that as examples.

You’ll need git and java installed for the network tomography tool to work. Maybe it’s obvious. When I went through the process, neither was installed on my bare RHEL v6.7 box. 

One important thing is the Java version. We’re at Java 7 (a.k.a. 1.7), not 8. We also use the OpenJDK flavor of Java, not Oracle’s. The tomography tool might work with other versions of Java, but this will work for sure, and you’ll install the same java that Euca will install anyway (so you don’t have extra versions installed, good):
yum install git java-1.7.0-openjdk
The Java 7 thing is mentioned in http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.0/#shared/intro_compatibility_matrix_4.2.html , so it must be important at some level.
I don’t think the version of git is important.

(It’s also referenced in the “Install Eucalyptus Release Packages” page, but it runs the same way.)

As for running the network-tomography tool:

You need to run it on every host in your installation at about the same time. The command line is exactly the same on each. You need to enter all the IPs including the one for the host you’re on. 

When you start it on a host, it does a 5-second countdown before sending packets over the network to the other machines. This is the output you see during that time: (part of the output from that email thread)
Sleeping for 5 seconds:  5 4 3 2 1  GO!

If you don’t have all the other hosts running it by then, you’ll get errors if you start one after the first host’s 5-sec delay. That makes it a bit challenging if you have lots of hosts to start them on within that 5 seconds. I paste the same command into each window, then click on each window and hit Enter as fast as I can. Maybe there oughta be a better way!

Then it runs for an undetermined amount of time (from a few minutes, to 2 hours 15 minutes!) before all windows hang, with no further output. I don’t know how it figures out when it’s done. We (dev) oughta investigate and maybe fix that so it’s more consistent. Anyway, you have to Ctrl-C or Ctrl-Break to stop it. Or kill the process from another session, looking for a process with “tomography” in the name - it’s a very long process name:

java -classpath /usr/share/network-tomography/lib/commons-cli-1.2.jar:/usr/share/network-tomography/lib/groovy-all-1.7.2.jar:/usr/share/network-tomography/lib/guava-r09.jar:/usr/share/network-tomography/lib/jansi-1.10.jar:/usr/share/network-tomography/lib/jgroups-2.11.1.Final.jar:/usr/share/network-tomography/lib/jline-1.0.jar:. -Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true -Dscript.name=/usr/bin/network-tomography -Dprogram.name=groovy -Dgroovy.starter.conf=/usr/share/network-tomography/lib/groovy-starter.conf -Dgroovy.home=/usr/share/network-tomography/lib/ -Dtools.jar=/lib/tools.jar org.codehaus.groovy.tools.GroovyStarter --main groovy.ui.GroovyMain --conf /usr/share/network-tomography/lib/groovy-starter.conf /usr/share/network-tomography/lib/network-tomography.groovy svr1 svr2 svr3
(with your own server names or IPs instead of “svr1 svr2 svr3”)

If you see any “bad” output as shown in Chris’s email, something’s wrong (I don’t know what). If you see nothing but good output, then you’re OK. Make sure your window saves all the output since it could be huge and scroll off the top of the window’s buffer depending on your terminal program.

If you see nothing but dots, like this:
Wed Nov 25 08:53:06 PST 2015 /10.111.5.126:5551->224.10.10.1 ttl=32 iface=br0
....................................................................................................
Wed Nov 25 08:53:10 PST 2015 /10.111.5.126:8761->228.7.7.1 ttl=32 iface=br0
....................................................................................................
…then the host is trying to connect to other hosts, and failing.

If it’s connected and exchanging packets, then you see the “colon-dot” pattern, like this:
Tue Nov 24 18:55:44 PST 2015 10.111.5.162 sent=100 sizes=(185,8192) ackd=100 lost-packets=[ count=0 sizes=[] ]
Tue Nov 24 18:55:44 PST 2015 10.111.5.126 sent=100 sizes=(185,8192) ackd=100 lost-packets=[ count=0 sizes=[] ]
Tue Nov 24 18:55:45 PST 2015 /10.111.5.139:8762->228.7.7.2 ttl=32 iface=br0
.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::
Tue Nov 24 18:55:48 PST 2015 10.111.5.162 sent=100 sizes=(185,8192) ackd=100 lost-packets=[ count=0 sizes=[] ]
Tue Nov 24 18:55:48 PST 2015 10.111.5.126 sent=100 sizes=(185,8192) ackd=100 lost-packets=[ count=0 sizes=[] ]
Tue Nov 24 18:55:49 PST 2015 /10.111.5.139:5552->224.10.10.2 ttl=32 iface=br0
.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::.::

10. http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/ Internal Web docs

I happened upon this site recently. I see the docs for each release, and master, in their subdirs. But there’s a set of really(?) old docs at that top level. Do they need to be removed or updated? Just curious.

11. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.0/#euca2ools-release-notes/rn_euca2ools_features_3.3.0.html

Nits:
"-w/--write-config option that allows them *to* create" (missing word)
"AWS signture version 4" (misspelling)

12. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.0/#install-guide/configure_imaging_service.html

"Specifically, in this release of Eucalyptus, there are three usage scenarios for the Eucalyptus Imaging Service: "
...but only 2 are listed. Was one removed? (What was it?) Or was a 3rd added that's missing?

comments.body:
[~lincoln.thomas] thanks for all the notes!
Quick summary of the items, after a quick glance:
1. bug to fix
2. bug to fix
3. bug to fix
4. bug to fix
5. but the doc reflects how it is _supposed_ to work, right?
_[~lincoln.thomas] Yes it does, further investigation revealed this is not an issue. Ignore._
6. bug to fix
7. resolved with DOC-1700
8. open with DOC-1717 - copied your comments to that ticket
9. open with DOC-1740 - copied your comments to that ticket - also EUCA-11758 related.
10. Probably, yes. Scott's decision.

[~lincoln.thomas] please let me know what updates you suggest in the Install Guide for tomography (versus the README change you plan to do in EUCA-11758). Hopefully DOC-1740 will provide more clarity on the future of the tool.
Added issue #11 since it's such a nit it's not worth a separate JIRA issue. Hope that's OK.
Added issue #12, minor. I'll stop adding nits to this JIRA issue once it goes into "In Progress" status.

OK [~lincoln.thomas] I've taken it (so you'll have to save the next feedback for another DOC ticket :) ).

11. easy fix
12. bug to fix (have a couple other related service image tickets)
